September 25, 2005: Fiction
POLAR SHIFT, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) Kurt
Austin must contend with the leader of an antiglobalization group who possesses
technology that has the potential to destroy all of humanity.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE HISTORIAN, by Elizabeth Kostova. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) A young woman's
quest to learn the truth about her father's life and her mother's death involves
research into Vlad the Impaler and Dracula.
POINT BLANK, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dillon Savich and Lacey
Sherlock — F.B.I. agents as well as husband and wife — pursue a violent couple.
HIGH DRUID OF SHANNARA: STRAKEN, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$26.95.) Accompanied by a dwarf and an elven princess, Pen Ohmsford must
save his aunt from exile; the final volume of a fantasy trilogy.
LIPSTICK JUNGLE, by Candace Bushnell. (Hyperion, $24.95.) Three women
struggle to balance their high-powered jobs and their messy home lives.
CHILL FACTOR, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A successful
magazine editor is trapped in her remote cabin with a man believed to be a serial
killer.
THE WIDOW OF THE SOUTH, by Robert Hicks. (Warner, $24.95.) After the
Battle of Franklin in 1864, a Tennessee woman turns over her plantation to
Confederate troops for use as a hospital — and also as a cemetery.
SLOW BURN, by Julie Garwood. (Ballantine, $25.95.) Terrible mishaps befall a
successful businesswoman in Charleston, S.C.
WITHOUT MERCY, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $25.95.) An American intelligence
agent and his British counterpart swear vengeance against an international terror
ring that has killed one of their number.
LIFEGUARD, by James Patterson and Andrew Gross. (Little, Brown, $26.95.)
Things go terribly awry when a lifeguard at a Florida resort agrees to take part in a
$5 million heist.
VANISH, by Tess Gerritsen. (Ballantine Books, $24.95.) A hospital patient takes
hostages, among them a detective who is about to give birth, to make a political
point.
REFLECTIONS OF A PEACEMAKER, by Mattie J. T. Stepanek. (Andrews
McMeel, $16.95.) The final volume of poems by a boy who died of muscular
September 25, 2005
Non-Fiction
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.)
A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and
foreign policy and presents an overview of globalization trends.
1776, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) An account of America's
founding year by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, focusing on the inexperienced
George Washington and heroic citizen soldiers.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
100 PEOPLE WHO ARE SCREWING UP AMERICA, by Bernard Goldberg.
(HarperCollins, $25.95.) The author of "Bias" takes aim at "Hollywood blowhards,"
"America bashers," rappers and others.
NEW RULES, by Bill Maher. (Rodale, $24.95.) The comedian and host of "Real
Time With Bill Maher" takes on everyone from President Bush to Bob Dylan.
THE FAIRTAX BOOK, by Neal Boortz and John Linder. (ReganBooks/
HarperCollins, $24.95.) A radio talk show host and a United States congressman
call for the abolishment of the federal income tax and the I.R.S.
BAIT AND SWITCH, by Barbara Ehrenreich. (Metropolitan/Holt, $24.) The author
of "Nickel and Dimed" explores the world of white-collar job hunting.
ON BULL----, by Harry G. Frankfurt. (Princeton University, $9.95.) A philosopher
attempts a theoretical understanding of a "vast and amorphous" phenomenon.
THE GAME, by Neil Strauss. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $29.95.) A writer
spends two years in the society of pickup artists.
CONFESSIONS OF A VIDEO VIXEN, by Karrine Steffans.
(Amistad/HarperCollins, $24.95.) A tell-all memoir by a dancer and actress who
has appeared in many hip-hop videos.
FROM PIECES TO WEIGHT, by 50 Cent. (MTV Books/Pocket Books, $23.) The
rapper's reflections on his youthful experience as a drug dealer and its continuing
effect on his life.
THE TENDER BAR, by J. R. Moehringer. (Hyperion, $23.95.) A coming-of-age
memoir of a fatherless boy for whom the regulars at a Long Island saloon become
a substitute family.
